original_subgoals: Open the image in Photoshop.
Open the image in Photoshop.
Open the image in Photoshop where you want to remove an object.
Open Photoshop and load the image you want to edit.
Open the image in Photoshop where you want to remove objects.

subgoal: Select the object you want to remove using a selection tool (such as the Lasso Tool, Quick Selection Tool, or Pen Tool).
original_subgoals: Select the Lasso Tool to make a selection around the object you want to remove.
Identify the object you want to remove from the image.
Select the Lasso tool by pressing 'L' on your keyboard.
Use the Lasso tool to draw a selection around the object you want to remove.
Start by selecting the object you want to remove using one of the selection tools: Quick Selection Tool (W), Lasso Tool (L), Polygonal Lasso Tool (L), Quick Mask Mode, or Pen Tool (P).
For Quick Selection Tool, select around the object and Photoshop will select the area inside.
For Lasso Tool, draw around the object. Hold spacebar to move the canvas if needed.
For Polygonal Lasso Tool, click to create straight lines around the object. Hold spacebar to move the canvas if needed.
For Quick Mask Mode, activate it, select the paintbrush (B), and paint over the object. Adjust brush size with alt + right click. Exit Quick Mask Mode to create a selection.
For Pen Tool, click to drop points and create a path around the object. Control-click the path to make it a selection.
Select the Lasso tool by pressing 'L' on your keyboard or finding it in the toolbar.
Create a selection around the object you want to remove, such as a car, by clicking and dragging around it.
If needed, expand the selection by going to Select > Modify > Expand. Use a value like 15 for expansion.
Set the feather to 10 pixels and ensure AntiAliased is checked in the Options bar.

subgoal: Duplicate the layer to have a clean copy behind for non-destructive editing.
original_subgoals: Duplicate the layer to have a clean copy behind.

subgoal: Use Content-Aware Fill to remove the object and fill the area. Adjust the sampling area if needed to improve the fill result.
original_subgoals: Use Content-Aware Fill by pressing Shift + Delete (Shift + Backspace on Windows) and select Content-Aware in the Fill dialog box.
Adjust the selection area using the Lasso Tool to improve the fill result.
Apply the Content-Aware Fill and deselect the selection (Ctrl + D).
Try using the Content-Aware Fill for better results. Select the object using the Polygonal Lasso Tool, then go to Edit > Content-Aware Fill and apply the default settings.
For complex areas where two objects are attached, use the Content-Aware Fill with careful selection to avoid affecting adjacent objects.
Go to the 'Edit' menu at the top of the screen.
Select 'Content-Aware Fill' from the dropdown menu.
Click 'OK' to apply the Content-Aware Fill.
Use Content-Aware Fill to remove the object. Press control + backspace, set contents to Content-Aware Fill, and ensure color adaptation is checked. Click OK.
For complex backgrounds, use Edit > Content-Aware Fill to manually select data for filling. Adjust opacity and color if needed, and use the preview to check the result.
Click on 'Generative Fill' in the Contextual taskbar. If it's not visible, go to Window > Contextual taskbar to reveal it.
Click 'Generate' without adding any specific prompt to create new pixels to replace the selected object.
In the tool window, the green area indicates the parts of the image Photoshop will use to sample for the fill.
Use the Eraser tool to remove any areas from the green selection that you don't want Photoshop to sample from (e.g., parts of the object you are removing).
Use the Spot Healing Brush Tool to paint over the object you want to remove. This tool may leave artifacts or imperfections.

To use the new Remove Tool, ensure you have the beta version of Photoshop installed. Open the Creative Cloud application, go to the Beta Apps section, and install Photoshop Beta if you haven't already.
In Photoshop Beta, find the Remove Tool inside the Healing group. Select it.
Paint over the object you want to remove with the Remove Tool. It should seamlessly remove the object with minimal artifacts.
If there are any imperfections, paint over them again with the Remove Tool to fix them.
Use the 'Remove After Each Stroke' option if you want the tool to apply changes after each stroke, or leave it off to apply changes after multiple strokes.
Remember that the Remove Tool is in beta, and Adobe is still refining it. Provide feedback if you encounter issues.
Enjoy experimenting with the new tool and explore its capabilities for different scenarios.

subgoal: For more control, use Edit > Content-Aware Fill to adjust settings and sampling areas.
original_subgoals: If the result is not satisfactory, go to Edit > Content-Aware Fill for more control.
Use the masking tool to exclude unwanted areas from the sample.

subgoal: Use the Clone Stamp Tool to refine the area by sampling from a clean area and painting over the object. Feather the selection slightly to soften the edges if needed.
original_subgoals: For final touch-ups, use the Clone Stamp Tool on a new layer, setting it to 'Current and Below'.
Sample the area you want to clone (Alt/Option + click) and paint over the area to clean up artifacts.

Remove the easy parts of the object using the Clone Stamp tool. Create a new layer and use the Pen tool to make a selection around the area you want to clone. Feather the selection slightly to soften the edges.
Use the Clone Stamp tool to sample from a clean area and paint over the object you want to remove. Deselect the selection when done.

subgoal: For non-destructive editing, create a new layer and enable 'Sample All Layers' in the tool options. This allows you to paint on a separate layer without affecting the original image.
original_subgoals: Create a new layer for retouching.
For non-destructive editing, create a new layer and enable 'Sample All Layers' in the Remove Tool options. This allows you to paint on a separate layer without affecting the original image.

subgoal: Use the Spot Healing Brush Tool to remove small objects or lines by clicking and dragging over them. Adjust the brush size as needed.
original_subgoals: To remove power lines, create a new layer and select the Spot Healing Brush Tool.
Enable 'Sample All Layers' and adjust the brush size with the left bracket key.
Click at the start of the power line, release, hold Shift, and click at the end to remove the line.

subgoal: Use the Vanishing Point filter to define the perspective of the image and clone areas in perspective.
original_subgoals: Define the perspective of the image by creating a new layer and using the Vanishing Point filter. Use the Create Plane tool to mark the four corners of the area you want to work on.
Adjust the perspective plane to match the perspective of the image accurately.

Use the Clone tool within the Vanishing Point filter to clone areas in perspective. Adjust the brush settings such as diameter, hardness, and opacity as needed. Decide whether to use the Healing option based on the desired effect.

subgoal: Use additional tools like the Clone Stamp Tool or Brush tool to refine the area and fix any issues with the fill. Clone small sections at a time to maintain control and ensure smooth blending.
original_subgoals: To remove braces, zoom in to 100% view (Ctrl/Command + 1).
Select the Brush Tool and sample the tooth color (Alt/Option + click).
Paint over the braces with the sampled color, using a soft brush with hardness set to 0.
Adjust the brush size and opacity as needed to blend the colors smoothly.
Clone small sections at a time to maintain control and ensure smooth blending.
Exit the Vanishing Point filter and use the Polygonal Lasso tool to select any remaining areas that need fixing.
Feather the selection slightly and use the Clone Stamp tool to fix any remaining defects.
If needed, make additional adjustments or repairs using the Remove Tool or other Photoshop tools.
For touch-ups, duplicate the layers (ctrl + j) and merge them (ctrl + e).
Use the Clone Stamp Tool to blend the area. Set flow to less than 5 and low opacity.
Hold alt and click to set a reference point, then paint to blend the area. Use small strokes and frequently set new reference points to avoid painting unwanted areas.
Continue blending until the removal is seamless.
For smaller areas or additional touch-ups, use the Remove tool. Create a new layer and enable 'Sample All Layers'.
Paint over the areas you want to remove with the Remove tool and press Enter to apply the changes.
Use the Remove tool to touch up the edges of the restored area, ensuring 'Sample All Layers' is enabled.
For final touch-ups, use the Lasso tool to create a smaller selection around specific areas and apply Generative Fill again.
To fix any issues with the Generative Fill, such as a distorted leg, use the Object Selection tool to select the original area you want to restore.
With the selection active, re-enable all layers and select the problematic Generative Fill layer.
Use the Brush tool with the foreground color set to black to paint inside the selection area on the Generative Fill layer mask to restore the original content.
Invert the selection to mask out any additional problem areas around the restored content.

subgoal: Review the fill results and select the best variation or adjust settings if needed. Save the result as a snapshot in the History panel for comparison.
original_subgoals: Deselect the selection and review the image for any final touch-ups.
Save the result as a snapshot in the History panel for comparison.
Deselect the selection using Ctrl or Command + D and save this result as another snapshot in the History panel.
A new tool window will open, showing the selected area and a preview of the fill result.
Once you have adjusted the sampling area, check the preview to ensure the object is removed cleanly.
If satisfied with the result, choose to output the result to a new layer.
Use brushes to refine the selection area in Content-Aware Fill, removing unwanted areas from the selection.
Once satisfied with the fill, click OK to apply it.
Review the variations provided in the Properties panel and select the one that looks best.

subgoal: Repeat the process for other objects you want to remove.
original_subgoals: Repeat the process for all power lines.
Repeat the process for each tooth to remove all braces.
Repeat the process for other objects you want to remove, such as cars in the background, using the Lasso tool and Generative Fill.

subgoal: Review the before and after to ensure all unwanted objects are removed and the image looks seamless. Compare the results of different tools using the snapshots saved in the History panel.
original_subgoals: Recap the steps: Remove easy parts, define perspective, clone in perspective, and finish with touch-ups.
Compare the results of different tools using the snapshots saved in the History panel.
Review the image to ensure the object has been removed satisfactorily.
Review the before and after to ensure all unwanted objects are removed and the image looks seamless.
